articles.content: Vallorcine Avalanche Kills Ski Patroller Amid Deadly Alpine Weekend A fatal avalanche in Vallorcine has claimed the life of a ski patroller working in the La Flégère sector of the Chamonix-Mont-Blanc domain. The tragedy occurred on Sunday and has since been confirmed as part of a deadly avalanche weekend across the French Alps , with at least six fatalities reported nationwide. According to updated reporting, the victim was a 32-year-old pisteur-secouriste , a father of young children, who was working on the mountain at the time of the avalanche. Despite a rapid response, he did not survive his injuries. A Weekend Marked by Multiple Avalanche Fatalities Authorities now confirm that the Vallorcine accident was not an isolated incident . articles.title: Crans-Montana Bar Not Safety Checked for Five Years
articles.description: A catalogue of errors is emerging following the fire at Le Constellation Bar in the Swiss resort that killed 40 people & injured 116. Questions are asked about regulation authorities. UPDATED The post Crans-Montana Bar Not Safety Checked for Five Years appeared first on PlanetSKI .
articles.content: The Mayor of Crans-Montana, Nicolas Feraud, has said that he could not explain why Le Constellation bar had not been checked in so long, but that the council was “profoundly sorry”. Venues in the Swiss ski resort should have been checked on a regular basis. “We regret that – we owe it to the families and we will accept the responsibility,” he said at a news conference. Taking repeated questions on why the bar had not been checked in so long, Feraud said: “I have no answer for you today.” “We’re profoundly sorry about that and I know how hard that will be for the families.” Sparklers on bottles being carried too close to the ceiling were the likely cause of the fire, a preliminary investigation has found. articles.content: Lindsey Vonn won four World Cup overall championships. She took the gold medal in the downhill at the 2010 Winter Olympics. They both retired at the peak of their powers in 2019 and went down as legends of alpine ski racing. Last season they both returned. Lindsey Vonn set to race again Hirscher is back 41-year old Vonn has had a fairy tale comeback that befits a team of Hollywood scriptwriters. She has had two victories in Downhill this season and is a favourite for gold at the Milan- Cortina Winter Olympics that takes place next month. Last weekend she extended her record as the oldest race winner in the 60-season history of the World Cup circuit. Her 84th career win on the circuit was her record-extending 45th in downhill. articles.content: What Overcrowded Slopes, High-Speed Lifts & Artificial Snow Mean for Your Safety Too Many Skiers on the Slopes? Crowding, Speed & Safety Explained If you’ve skied during peak weeks in recent seasons, you’ve probably felt it: busier slopes, faster lifts, more people moving at very different speeds — all at once. While skiing has always involved risk, many skiers are now asking a valid question: Are modern ski resorts becoming less safe — not because of the mountains, but because of how many of us are on them at the same time? Let’s break this down in a realistic, skier-to-skier way , without panic — just facts, context, and common sense. 1. When Slopes Get Crowded, Risk Goes Up (It’s Simple Physics) Crowding doesn’t just affect your enjoyment — it changes how accidents happen . Studies on ski injuries consistently show that: Collision risk increases with slope density Most serious accidents happen on groomed runs , not off-piste The biggest factor is not equipment — it’s human behaviour

articles.content: Last week, the SIA team attended the Ski Industry Climate Summit, hosted by Atomic, and the Winter Sports Sustainability Network’s (WSN) winter meeting during ISPO in Munich. Over 200 ski industry leaders came together, showcasing remarkable collaboration among the sector’s biggest hardgoods brands – united to share ideas, data, and best practices. The focus was clear: the most effective way that the global winter outdoor industry can implement large-scale sustainability and climate action measures is by coming together to collaborate and share the expertise we have. A large part of this urgency is driven by the upcoming EU sustainability regulations, which will enforce stricter requirements on disclosure, traceability, waste, circularity, deforestation, and more. Notably, these regulations affect not only EU-based businesses but also U.S. companies operating in the European market. articles.content: Madison, WI, January 1, 2025– Effective January 1, Midwest Winter Sports Reps Association (MWSRA) and Outdoor Reps Association (ORA) will merge to form Midwest Professional Reps Organization, or M-Pro. The new group will be an all-season resource for sales reps and retailers in outdoor, winter sports, and the various categories that touch them. Founded in the 70s (MWSRA) and 80s (ORA), the two predecessor organizations have for decades provided trade shows and informational resources to facilitate rep/retailer relationships. With substantial member overlap, the two boards of directors proposed a merger and the combined membership voted overwhelmingly to approve. The new organization is currently planning 4 shows per year, 2 summer and 2 winter, with one per season in Saint Paul, MN and Madison, WI. articles.title: British Skier Among Six Dead in Multiple Avalanches in French Alps
articles.description: Three people died on Saturday and three more on Sunday. The British fatality was skiing in La Plagne. NEW The post British Skier Among Six Dead in Multiple Avalanches in French Alps appeared first on PlanetSKI .
articles.content: It has been a grim weekend and follows heavy snowfall with the authorities advising extreme caution if venturing off piste. In many areas there has been a Level 4 risk, meaning there is a ‘high’ possibility of avalanches. The British fatality on Sunday in La Plagne was man in his 50s who was caught in an avalanche while skiing off the marked runs in a group. More than 50 rescuers searched for him and found the man buried under 2.5m of snow after nearly an hour of searching. He was pronounced dead at the scene. The authorities say he was not wearing an avalanche transceiver. Elsewhere on Sunday a skier died in an avalanche in Courchevel in Les3Vallees. There was also an avalanche in Orelle in Les3Vallees on Sunday and a victim was taken to the hospital of Saint-Jean-de-Maurienne. The person’s condition has not been released and it is understood the victim was not wearing a transceiver. In Vallorcine near Chamonix a 32-year-old ski paroller skier died after being caught in an avalanche.

articles.title: Rocky Mountain National Park Snowboarder & Snowboarder Caught In Avalanche (VIDEO)
articles.description: Always stay vigilant with avalanche forecasting, spacing, and group protocols in the backcountry.
articles.content: The following video captured January 10, 2026 documents an human triggered avalanche in within Rocky Mountain National Park . A group of three backcountry skiers/riders was descending the line. They intentionally ski-cut the upper chute to test the slope, which triggered a wind slab avalanche that released and swept clear part of the upper terrain, carrying one member with it. As the third skier entered the untouched lower section of the slope, the snow fractured above him, producing an 8–14 inch crown. He was caught, carried downslope, briefly buried, and managed to self-arrest by grabbing a tree — though the impact dislocated his shoulder in the process. While the other two hurried down to assist their injured partner, another rider was caught in a secondary slide (likely a hangfire triggered by their movement). articles.title: This Might Be The Wildest Photo Finish In Ski Race History
articles.description: This ski cross race at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics started out pretty normal, but it ended with one of the most dramatic photo finishes in sport history.
articles.content: This ski cross race at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics started out pretty normal, but it ended with one of the most dramatic photo finishes in sport history, let alone ski racing history. The race was the men’s ski cross quarter-final. The top two finishers would continue to the semi-final, and it looked like Swedish skier Victor Oehling Norberg and Russian skier Egor Korotkov had it locked down heading into the final jump. Unfortunately both Oehling Norberg and Egor Korotkov wiped out alongside Finish skier Jouni Pellinen, leaving the finish line wide open for Swiss skier Armin Niederer. Niederer took first, and the other three went to a photo finish. The photo made it evident that the Russian skier, Korotkov, had taken second, meaning he and Niederer would move on to the semi-finals. Korotkov wound up finishing in 5th overall for the men’s ski cross, and Niederer in 7th place. articles.title: Lindsey Vonn Continues Incredible Comeback With Fourth Podium in Four Downhills
articles.description: Lindsey Vonn continued her amazing comeback on Saturday, claiming her second downhill World Cup victory of the 2025-26 season.
articles.content: Alpine skiing legend Lindsey Vonn continued her extraordinary comeback on Saturday, claiming her second downhill World Cup victory of the 2025-26 season in Zauchensee, Austria. The 41-year-old American, who retired in February 2019 and returned to competition in December 2024 after a partial knee replacement, recorded her 84th career World Cup win with a dominant time of 1:06.24 on a shortened, snowy course. She finished 0.37 seconds ahead of Norway’s Kajsa Vickhoff Lie, while fellow American Jacqueline Wiles took third. “What an incredible day!! On the podium again with my teammate Jackie Wiles! Last time we were on the podium together was Cortina 2018 right before the Olympics in Korea. So proud of you Jackie!! You’ve been through so much and fought so hard. articles.title: Skier Secures First S&S Couloir Send Of The 2025-26 Season
articles.description: The infamous S&S Couloir at Jackson Hole is open for the season, and at least one daring soul has already taken it on.
articles.content: Teton Village, Wyoming — Corbet’s Couloir gets all the hype, but its neighbor is probably the toughest inbounds run not only at Jackson Hole, but maybe the whole country. S&S Couloir required skiers to ride a rock wall down onto the snow and then make a sharp turn to avoid slamming into the rocks. Wile E. Coyote would be proud of you, though. Only the best skiers can put their instincts together for this one. In this video by Killerkilmain’s dad , a skier reportedly is the first to make turns on S&S Couloir for the season. In prior videos, I’ve seen the rock face look a bit snowier. This time around, the skier got a nice base grind out of it. The video is a great showcase of what makes Jackson Hole and its skier different. “Wow” is right. articles.title: Two People Die in Avalanches in Italy
articles.description: The accidents happened in Piedmont and in the north eastern Italian region of Veneto. Poor weather hindered rescue efforts. The post Two People Die in Avalanches in Italy appeared first on PlanetSKI .
articles.content: A first avalanche hit the southwest Alpine Maira Valley, near the French border in the Italian region of Piedmont. It killed one person and injured two others. One of them is in critical condition. Rescue teams had to set out on foot as strong winds prevented helicopters from taking off. In the north eastern Italian region of Veneto, an avalanche on the Vajo Gabene slope in the Small Dolomites killed a 50-year-old ski mountaineer. Rescue teams reached him by helicopter but were unable to save him. A combination of heavy snowfall and strong winds has raised avalanche risks across some parts of the Alps in recent days. A second avalanche occurred near Pragelato – a ski area about 60 km to the west of Turin. A woman caught in the avalanche was able to free herself, but was unable to move because of injuries. articles.content: Glacial and Periglacial Risk in the Alps: What Authorities Are Being Told to Do For decades, glaciers in the Alps were treated as slow, predictable features of the mountain landscape . Today, that assumption no longer holds. A new technical document published by Fondazione Montagna Sicura , in collaboration with Italy’s Civil Protection system and scientific partners, makes this very clear: glacial and periglacial areas are becoming more unstable, more unpredictable, and more dangerous — and everyone involved in mountain management needs to adapt. The report, “Glacial and Periglacial Risk in Alpine Environments – A Methodological Framework” , is not written for tourists. It is written for the people responsible for keeping mountain regions safe — and its recommendations reveal how deeply climate change is reshaping the Alps. Photo: Mauro Hernandez. Unsplash. articles.content: Why Foehn Winds Matter for Avalanche Safety Foehn winds are a well-known meteorological phenomenon in the Alps, but their impact on avalanche risk is often underestimated by skiers and snowboarders. While foehn conditions are sometimes associated with clear skies and warmer temperatures , they can significantly destabilise the snowpack , increasing the likelihood of dangerous slab avalanches , especially in off-piste and backcountry terrain. What Are Foehn Winds? Foehn winds are strong, dry downslope winds that occur when air masses cross the Alps and descend on the leeward side, warming rapidly as they lose moisture. They are common across: Italian Alps Swiss Alps Austrian Alps French Alps In Italy, foehn is often referred to as favonio , while in Austria and Germany it is known as Föhn . Wind slab.
